text: A gigantic aerial shot. Postwar autos fill the muggy mids evening air with the sounds of thousands of HONKING HORNS mere precursor to the traffic yet to come. Darkened outly neighborhoods are evidence of the postwar home constructi boom, as scores of stucco bungalows are being built in th areas surrounding the beating heart of the town, a swath garishly bright concrete called HOLLYWOOD BOULEVARD.
Of course, it's not like the postcards  say it is. This is what it's like.  I'm Pete Appleton, and this is my  town.

Still in the same shot, we rocket down into the center of the intersection of Hollywood and Vine, then head west al the boulevard, skimming just above the traffic -- past Mu and Frank's Grill and the Hollywood Canteen, past the Egy Theater and a rumbling Pacific Electric Red Car, across  Highland Avenue, past the Paramount Theater, and across t street to GRAUMAN'S CHINESE THEATER.

Born and raised here, thank you very  much. Sometimes, it seems like  everyone here is from somewhere else.  But everyone loves the movies, so  Hollywood is everyone's town, and  they come here by the busload. To  them, Grauman's Chinese Theater is  just about the most exciting place  on the planet. To me, it's the theater  that's playing "The African Queen."

And like the man said, the film on the marquee is "THE AF QUEEN."  Still the same shot, buses disgorge TOURISTS, wh move into the forecourt of the theater. The MEN doff thei hats and mop their brows. The WOMEN pull their blouses aw from their chests, fanning themselves with movie-star map as they marvel at the signed cement blocks. We MOVE AMONG THEM, until we pick up A COUPLE, and we sta behind them as they work their way through the crowd, on  their way to
where an ornately attired DOORMAN smiles and tears their  tickets.
Newsreel's just starting, folks.

That's me and my girlfriend. Her  name is Sandra Sinclair, and this is  her town, too -- she's from Cleveland.   She came out here to be an actress,  and that's just what she's doing.  The first picture I ever wrote, a  little potboiler called "Sand Pirates  of the Sahara." Okay, it ain't  "Citizen Kane," but you gotta start  somewhere.

an explosion of glitz mixed with Chinese myth and legend. Everywhere you look, it's red and orange and plush carpet and golden light. We MOVE THROUGH the lobby, still in the same shot, still tracking the couple, heading for the  auditorium doors, which are swept open by two ramrod-erec USHERS and we move into THE DARKENED THEATER. As the couple, Pete and Sandra, find seats, we HEAR the  soundtrack of the film before we see the screen, the  unmistakable strains of a march, and then -- still in the same shot -- we see the screen... A NEWSREEL. As the march SWELLS to a crescendo, we HEAR THE NEWSREEL
Bringing the news of the world to  you!
Over a newsreel shot of a packed Congressional Committee  Hearing Room, a title blares "HOLLYWOOD REDS GO TO JAIL!"

Four years ago, in one of filmland's  darkest hours, ten men, the so-called  "Hollywood Ten," were called to  testify before the House Committee  of Un-American Activities,  investigating the proliferation of  the dreaded Red Menace in Hollywood.
We see several shots of WITNESSES engaged in heated verba battles with congressmen, especially Committee Chairman T JOHNSTON DOYLE and the Majority Counsel, ELVIN CLYDE.

Refusing to answer the lawmaker's  questions, cowering behind the Fifth  Amendment's protection against self- incrimination, the ten motion picture  writers dared Congress to come after  them. Well, come after them they  did! And after years of court  wrangling, it's now time to pay the  piper!
Over shots of several of the "Hollywood Ten" being led to jail in handcuffs, the newsreel narration continues.

And so, it's off to jail, the charge:  Contempt of Congress! This should  give you fellas something to write  about now! A new round of  investigations begins this fall, the  mandate: Get the reds out of  Hollywood!

In the audience, one man YELLS "Lock up the commie bastar and a few others cheer and laugh. As the newsreel moves o to a somewhat more innocuous subject, we WHEEL AROUND AND... ENDFRAME ON PETE APPLETON AND SANDRA SINCLAIR. Pete's a handsome fellow in his 30s, and Sandra's a starl pretty girl in her mid-20s. As she rummages in her purse, Pete watches the newsreel.
Pete, there's time before the picture  starts, you want to get some popcorn?
You bet, honey.
Pete kisses Sandra on the cheek, then stands and sprints the aisle to the concession stand, a big unworried grin o his face.
We were young, we were in love, and  we were working in pictures. Life...  was good.

Pete pulls up to the guard kiosk in his spiffy yellow  convertible Plymouth. The Guard, RAY, steps out to meet h Pete lights up a cigarette. We get a better sense of him  now. Though earnest, he's jocular, and a bit of a fast ta
(very chipper) Mornin', Ray. Whaddya know whaddya  say? Me and Sandra caught "The African  Queen" at the Chinese last night.  Great picture, great picture.
Ray is nonplussed. Tips his hat. Regards Pete suspiciousl
Mr. Appleton.
What's with this "Mr. Appleton" crap?   Your boss hiding in there?
You're clear to go in.
What's that mean?
Ray heads back to his kiosk, shaking his head.
Have a pleasant day.
Pete, covering his worry well, drives onto the lot.
Pete pulls up, hops out, grinds out his cigarette, looks  around and goes inside.
Pete comes down the hall a few steps, stops. Something's  wrong. It's awfully quiet. He pokes his head into the doo marked "TYPING POOL."

A sea of black Underwoods -- all silent. The lights in th room are off, and hard shafts of morning sun stream in th the windows. One typists, LOUISE, is going from machine t machine, pulling covers over them.
Louise... what gives?
She looks up, startled.
Oh Pete... they, uh, they gave  everybody the day off... while they  sort things out.
Sort what out? Are my pages done?
They took 'em.
They took 'em? Who took 'em? Louise,  what's going on...
Pete, I'm not even supposed to be  talking to you...
She rushes past him. Pete doesn't quite know what to thin
Good morning, Peter.
Pete turns. The voice belongs to Pete's agent, LEO KUBELS a rotund man in his fifties. He wears a perfectly tailore silk suit.
Leo... what's going on?

FROM FAR AWAY, we watch as Leo and Pete come out of the  Writer's Building and join a flood of DRESS EXTRAS, all d up in Puritan pilgrim garb and heading for the commissary As they move through the mob and emerge on the other side it's clear that Pete is reeling from something he's just  been told.
Peter, their hands are tied. You see  that, don't you?
I... I don't believe this.
Are you saying it's a mistake, that  you didn't go to any meetings? They  say you did.
Who the hell is this "they?"
Congress, the FBI, Red Channels, it  don't matter who the hell "they" is.  "They" know who "they" are, that's  all that matters. (deliberately) Now, did you go to any meetings?

(on the spot) No. Yeah... I... I don't know. Maybe  I did. Leo, this was before Pearl  Harbor. I was in college. It was a  bunch of kids, and I was just one of  'em. I didn't believe in what they  were saying. Hell, I didn't even  know what they were saying!
So, you're saying that it's true.  You went to a meeting of a known  communist organization.
Leo, I was trying to impress a skirt.  You know me, I'm non-political.  Republican, Democrat, Communist,  there's not a dime's worth of  difference between 'em anyway.
You should watch what you say.
I don't know who fingered me, but  I'm not a communist!
Kid, that cuts no ice with them.
(frustrated) What? That I'm accused of being a  communist when I don't happen to be  one?
They know you were at that meeting,  Peter. They've been told, and they  know.
Leo, you're my agent. Tell "them" to  take a flyin' piss. I didn't do  anything wrong. I fought in the war,  for crissakes!
Fought? Come on, Pete, you ran the  PX at Fort Dix.
I was decorated.
I know. A Purple Heart.
Exactly.
You broke your arm. You were coming  out of a bar. You were drunk.
At least I was on our side! Look,  they want me to testify? I'll testify.  I'll tell 'em anything they want to  hear! Jesus, Leo, this is my career!
You can't testify.
Why not?
Leo takes a gold cigarette care from his breast pocket, o a cigarette to Pete and takes one for himself.

Don't take this personally, kid. If  it were up to me, I'd have you testify  wearing your uniform and your medal,  wrapped in a flag with one hand on  your heart and the other hand on a  bible. What can I say? I like you.
Leo lights Pete's cigarette and his own. Puts a fatherly  hand on his shoulder.
They don't want you to testify because  you're not a big enough fish for  them. They just don't want you writing  pictures for now. That's all.
(under his breath) Yeah, well, that's enough.
Peter, I believe in you. More to the  point, I read your new script...  um...
"Ashes To Ashes?"

That's the one, "Ashes To Ashes." I  think it's great. But it'll never  get made with this communist business  hanging over your head. You can't  work until you're cleared -- and  believe me, starting right now, I'm  gonna do everything I can to make  that happen.
So, it is a blacklist.
(defensive) Don't say that. There is no such  thing as a blacklist. (calm) Now, are you gonna play ball?
(sullenly) Yes. (then, pissed) Leo, goddammit... this isn't fair!
Leo blows out a thin stream of smoke.
(hand on Pete's  shoulder) Kid, this is the United States  Government we're talkin' about. Fair  ain't the point.

Prominent on the wall is a framed "SAND PIRATES OF THE SA poster. Pete reaches up and takes it down. He leans it up against the desk, then sits heavily in the wooden swivel  chair. He swivels around to see

standing by the door. He's watching Pete's every move. Two boxes sit on the desk, partially packed with Pete's  belongings. Pete lights a cigarette and opens the lower d drawer. He pulls out a stack of scripts and sets them on desk. He looks at the cover of the first one:
By Peter Appleton A United Pictures Production February 19, 1951
Pete shuffles the scripts and looks at the cover of the s one:
By Peter Appleton

He jams the scripts into one box and turns to the other b which contains somewhat more personal items. A ragged gol pillow with tassels. Legal pads of notes. An old tin-toy  fire truck, its bright red paint chipped and worn. He tur it around in his hands.
(musing) Huh. Red...
Footsteps approach, and Pete swivels toward the door.
Pete? Pete...?
Sandra appears in the doorway. She's in costume -- a Loui XIV courtier. She bustles past the Guard, rushes to Pete embraces him.
Oh, Pete...
They kiss. The Guard watches their every move.
What happened?
What exactly did you hear?
That you got let go.
I wasn't alone. Wasn't Frankie Ruskin  directing the picture you're in?
He was, but he got sick. We got a  new director today. Why?
Well, whatever Frankie's got, it's  catching.
You mean, he was... let go, too?
(sotto, an appeal) They're saying I'm a communist, Sandy.  But I'm not, you know that. I'm gonna  fight 'em, and I'm gonna win, but  I'll need your help.
During this last, Sandra has been ever-so-slightly pullin away from Pete.
A lot of good people are being accused  of things they didn't do. Hell, even  if I was a communist, this is America,  goddammit, a person should be able  to be whatever they want to be!   Right?
Sandra glances at the Guard, who is watching everything.
(nervously) Of course, but I... I don't know how  I... how much help I can be to you.  This is the sort of thing... someone  saying you're a communist... it can  ruin your career.
Pete sees where this is going. She's edging toward the do
Will you help me, Sandy?
I'll have to think about this. I  have to get back... I should go...
And she's out the door and gone in the blink of an eye.   Pete looks at the Guard.
So nice to be a pariah.

The Guard turns away. Pete moves back toward the boxes. Rummaging again, he comes up with a bottle of Jack Daniel with barely one swig left. He regards the bottle for a mo looks to see if the Guard is watching (he isn't), pops th cork, puts it to his lips and drains it. He looks at it  thoughtfully as we
A HALF-FULL BOTTLE OF JACK DANIELS setting down on a bart

The bottle is in front of Pete, who sits at the bar, quie getting stewed.  The Frolic Room is a classic Hollywood d dimly lit and full of character and characters. It's a qu night and getting quieter, as several PATRONS are just  leaving, waving goodbye to the bartender, JERRY, early 40 Jerry turns to Pete, eyes him suspiciously from the end o the bar. Pete picks up the bottle and pours another shot. Good boy, he got most of it in the glass.
Pete. You think maybe you've had  enough?
Bought the bottle, didn't I? (raises the shot) To the United States of America.  Long my she wave.
He knocks it back and Jerry pours him another.
(trying to light a  smoke) Thanks, Jerry. Tell me something.
What.
You tight with J. Edgar Hoover?
(helps Pete light his  cigarette) The G-man?
(thickly) Zackly.
Pete, if J. Edgar Hoover walked in  here wearing a dress, I wouldn't  know him.
Too bad. He says I'm a communist.
(glancing around) You should watch what you say. You  don't know who's listening.
You know I'm not a communist, don't  you, Jer?
Sure, I suppose. That why you're on  a bender?
This is not a bender yet. This is  the start of a bender. But I can see  how you were confused, they look a  lot alike.
Pete drains his shotglass, puts it back on the bar. He wa Jerry, who is not about to refill it. Pete reaches for th bottle, but Jerry is faster.
Pete... go home. Come on, I'll call  that girlfriend of yours, what's her  name... Sandy?
(laughs) Sandra Sinclair.
Gimmee her number, I'll have her  pick you up.

Sandra Sinclair. Wanna know her real  name? Bella Iskowitz. No one's who  they really are, Jer. Everyone's  someone else. Even you. Even me.  Especially me. I'm Peter Appleton,  the communist who's not really a  communist.
I wanna close up soon. C'mon, let's  call her.
Peter stands, stubs out his smoke, drops a few crumpled b on the bar and grabs his hat.
Nope. Can't. We're through.
Then I'll call you a cab.
I'll save you the trouble. (beat) I'm a cab. There. Did it myself.
Pete's preoccupied with putting on his hat and getting hi car keys out of his coat pocket, a daunting task in his  condition.
'Sides, car's right outside. I'll be  seein' ya, Jer.
Pete...
And he's out the door.
Pete takes a few steps, stumbles, stops, takes a deep bre then totters briskly towards his car. He hauls the door o and sits inside heavily.
Sitting slumped against the steering wheel, Pete looks as though he could fall asleep right there, which would prob be a good idea.
(mumbling) Drive. Drive. Bad idea. Too drunk to  drive.
He looks at his watch.
One-thirty. Huh! Early. Can't go  home yet.

He turns the key and hits the starter. The engine hums to life. Pete sits up, opens his eyes wide, shakes off the h and puts the car in gear. The Plymouth lurches forward a few yards, screeches to a  halt and stalls.
Oops.
He re-starts the car, puts it in gear, and pulls away and down the deserted boulevard.

The full moon is low over the ocean. Pete's car is parked the edge of the sand, the water fifty yards away. The fer wheel and the roller coaster of the amusement pier are da and eerie silhouettes, lit only by moonlight. Pete is asl in the driver's seat, head tilted back, his hat covering face, snoring. The waves CRASH against the pilings and startle Pete awak
Huh? Whatsa...
Instantly, he grabs his head.
I had no idea how I got to Santa  Monica, but it certainly was a good  idea. I don't think I could've faced  the headache I had alone in my  apartment. At least I had the ocean  air.
Pete takes a deep breath... and starts coughing. He gets his cigarettes and lights up. He takes a puff and glances his watch.
Three forty-five. I had only been  there for a couple of hours at most.   Truth be told, I was still fairly  drunk.
He starts the car and heads for the highway.
I'd head north until the sun came up  or I ran out of gas, whichever came  first.
Pete drives along the moonlit two-lane blacktop. Waves cr to the shore below the roadway.

Pete is finally relaxed. He takes off his hat and jams it down in the back seat. He takes a deep breath -- with the wind in his hair, a smile grows on his face and he seems peace. He glances down at the speedometer -- then at the  fuel gauge.
Pinning on "empty."
Shit.
Guess which came first.
He scans the road ahead -- nothing. Glances to his right.

The lights of a small town can be seen off in the distanc Pete veers the car off the highway and makes the turn tha will take him toward the lights. He passes a hand-painted sign that gives him hope: "GAS - 1 MI."
Pete's car rolls up and stops. There's a light on the sig and another in the station's window, but the place is  deserted.
I should've known better than to  think that a service station in the  sticks would be open at this hour,  but it wasn't like I had a lot of  choices.
Pete looks ahead toward the town. Its few lights twinkle the distance.
What the hell. At least there'd be a  diner opening in a couple of hours.  I'd get some pie and coffee, and  then I could worry about the gas.
Pete pulls out onto the road.
Pete's car trundles along, blowing past a hand-painted  roadside sign which reads:
NARROW BRIDGE - SINGLE LANE - NO GUARDRAIL
Pete's headlights catch a glimpse of another sign, readin "LAWSON WASH," just in front of a small wooden auto bridg Barely reducing his speed, Pete heads onto the bridge...
...his headlights pick up the glowing eyes of a hapless  possum... Pete swerves to avoid the animal, and a wheel drops off t edge...
...and the Plymouth careens over the side of the bridge a into the rapidly-moving water below!

The water is flowing very quickly, and the current is int Pete pulls himself out of the driver's seat (thankfully,  it's a convertible) and swims over the windshield. But... his left sleeve is caught on the door handle. Near out of breath and panicking, Pete shucks off the jacket a heads for the surface.
Pete breaks the surface and gasps for air. His fight isn' over yet, as the current is pulling him rapidly downstrea He swims with all his might toward the far bank.
Drained, Pete pulls himself out of the water and staggers his feet.
(gasping) Oh my god! I don't believe... oh my  god...

He stumbles along backwards a couple of steps... and his  heel hits a rock... Pete falls backward -- and his head strikes a glancing bl on another rock. He rolls down the bank, unconscious, and lands face down in the mud. CUT TO BLACK. IN BLACK, we slowly become aware of a panting, breathing  sound -- the sound of a dog...
A yellow labrador, full frame. It takes a couple more sni then starts licking furiously.
Maggie, whatcha got there? Huh, girl?  Whatcha find?
Pete is still laying face down on the bank, being fervent licked in the face by the dog.
A no-nonsense sort in his late-60s, he wears overalls and old railroad cap. He comes down to Pete, and using his wa stick, pokes him in the side.
Mister, who are ya? My dog likes  you, but that don't mean much, she  likes skunks, too. Sweet n'stupid,  that's why I keep her.
Pete blinks up at the Old Man, his mouth gaping open.
Mister, you okay? You look wet. You  in an accident or somethin'?
I... I don't know.
He sits up, and the Old Man gets a look at his head, whic is caked with mud and blood on one side.
You best come with me. Can ya walk?
I... yes, I think so.
He stands up shakily. The Old Man gives Pete a hand.
Come on, we'll have the Doc look you  over.
My head hurts.
I shouldn't be surprises. You smell  like that was quite a night before  you had there. (to the dog) Maggie! Let's go now!
And they head toward the road to town. BOOMING UP, we SEE them pass a roadside sign:
Name's Stanton Lawson. My ancestors  founded this town.
Ancestors?
Actually, my grandpap. But "ancestors"  sounds better, don't it? (hands Pete a  handkerchief) Here.
Pete takes the handkerchief and wipes the mud and some of the blood off his face.
I suppose. Thanks.
You look familiar, fella. What's  your name?
Pete stops, thinks for a moment.
I'm... I... I honestly don't know.

Pete and Stanton walk along Commerce Street, the main dra through the center of the small town. Lawson is a bit run down, creeping inexorably toward decrepit. Despite that,  there's a timeless quality to the small buildings, a fami All-American feel. Several of the PEOPLE walking along the street take notic of Pete and nod to Stanton, who nods back.
They all know you?
'Course they all know me. And I know  all them. Town's got my name, don't  it?
They pass the window of the drug store, COLE'S PHARMACY.

in the window with two faded photos, all decked in tatter black crepe. Two boys, no more than 18 and 19, who went o to war and didn't come back. Stanton notes Pete stopping to look at the stars and phot
Ernie Cole here just got himself  elected mayor. Lost both his boys in  the war. Kenny at Anzio and Willie  at Normandy.
(thinking) The war...
(points across the  street) Mabel over there at the diner lost  her husband Max. Okinawa, I believe.
A typical small-town greasy spoon -- with one faded star  prominent in the window.
On MABEL LANIER, a sweet-faced woman in her 30s. She star vacantly into space, her reverie broken by a customer nee a coffee refill.

All told, this little town gave sixty- two of its finest to the war.  Seventeen of 'em at Normandy alone.  More'n its share, I should say. Got  us a letter from President Truman.  City council commissioned a war  memorial. Been sittin' in the basement  of city hall these six years. Town  never had the heart to put it up.  Place just hasn't been the same since  the war.
Pete looks longingly toward the diner. Stanton takes note
You hungry, son?
Yes. Very.
Got any money?
Pete rummages in his pants pockets, and comes up with thr quarters.
Six bits. More'n enough to buy some  breakfast. C'mon.
And they head across the street.

head_text.subj: A PLATE WITH TWO PIECES OF APPLE PIE

text: A fork comes into frame and tears into one of the slices.
Pete is fairly shoveling the pie into his mouth, pausing  only to wash it down with gulps of coffee.

stands nearby, watching in amazement as her pie is consum in record time. Pete notices that Stanton and Mabel -- and the other PATR for that matter -- are watching his feeding frenzy. He st in his tracks, and starts chewing leisurely. He smiles at Mabel.
(mouth full) Pie's... good.
(wryly) Like you could tell. (to Stanton) Where'd you find him?
Down by the wash.
We gotta put a rail on that thing  before someone else gets killed. (to Pete) Three people have died there, Mister.   You're lucky to be alive.
(draining the coffee  cup) Thanks. More coffee?
Mabel obliges. As she pours the coffee, she looks at Pete
You know, you look familiar. You  ever been in here before?
Pete shakes his head.
He don't remember who he is, Mabel.  Gonna take him to the Doc, as soon  as he gets in.
(distractedly) Doc should be in for his coffee and  bear claw any minute... (to Pete) You sure you never been in here?
Pete looks up at Mabel and smiles winningly.
I'd remember this pie.
Mabel, thoroughly charmed, smiles back at Pete.
(patting his hand) I'll just get you another piece.

A stoop-shouldered little man in his late 60s, HARRY TRUM shambles along the street, headed for Mabel's Diner. Ther a sadness about Harry, the world-weary melancholy of a ma who has little to smile about because he has little to ca about. After a couple of steps, he's met up by DOC BEN  LARDNER, a vigorous man in his 50s. He comes up behind Ha and claps him on the back.
'Mornin' Harry. Fine day, isn't it?
Morning, Doc. Yes, yes it looks just  fine.
Plenty to do today?
(vaguely) Oh, yes, plenty. Plenty.
They're at the door of the diner. Doc opens it for Harry.
After you.
Lardner comes over to Mabel, who hands him a tall paper c of coffee and bags him a bear claw.
Mornin' Mabel, Stan.
Mornin' Doc. Got some new business  for you today.
Lardner and Pete make eye contact, and the doctor notices the bump on his head.
Hello, son. How'd that happen?
He don't know. And he don't know his  name, neither. Found him down by the  wash.
You'd better come with me, son. (to Mabel, indicating  the coffee and danish) On my tab?
You bet.
Lardner, Stanton and Pete rise and move to the door. Pete turns back, takes the three quarters out of his pocket, a puts them on the counter, smiling brightly at Mabel.
Thanks. Great pie.
(blushing) You're welcome. Come again.
seated at the opposite end of the counter. He glances up Pete.
as Pete smiles at Mabel and turns to go.
His mouth falls open, his hand moves to cover it. He's ju seen a ghost... HARRY'S POV - SLOW MOTION... ...as the three men pass by the diner's window.
(wide eyed) Sweet Jesus...
moving left-to-right, right-to-left through space.
Follow my finger. Just use your eyes.  That's it. Good.
Doc Lardner is checking Pete's eyes. Pete sits on an  examination table, his shirt off, his head freshly bandag Stanton lurks in the corner, Maggie curled at his feet.
He was passed out cold. Maggie woke  'im.
Uh-huh. He looks familiar. (to Pete) Open your mouth. Say "ah."
Pete does. Lardner has a look as Stanton pulls out a pock watch.
Said as much myself, Doc. Can't place  him, though. To look at him, you'd  think the cheese slid off his cracker. (looks at his watch) Well, morning's half-over. I'm off.
Thank you, Mr. Lawson.
Don't mention it. Whoever-you-are.
Stanton and Maggie exit. Lardner checks Pete's ears.
Any idea how you got here, son?
No, sir.
Lardner sniffs him.
Been drinkin' a bit, have we?
I don't remember. I guess so. Smells  like it. (smacks his lips and  frowns) Tastes like it.
Well, you've been wet to the skin.  You must've fallen in.
I guess I did.
Lucky you got out, that water's got  quite a pull, and it empties straight  into the ocean.
Lardner takes a shirt off his counter and hands it to Pet
Here, one of mine.
Thanks.
Pete puts on the shirt.
Do you remember if you were driving  a car? Maybe you went over the bridge.  No guard rail there, it's easy to  do. It's happened before.
It's possible. I just don't remember.
And you don't know your name or who  you are, that right?
(frustrated) I... no, I... I just can't...
(gently) It's okay, son. We just need to call  you something. That's all.
Pete stifles a laugh.
What is it?
Call me... Ishmael?
Well, at least you remember "Moby  Dick."
Lardner is on the phone, sipping his coffee and nibbling bear claw. Pete is standing, nosing around the office --  diplomas, photographs, knick-knacks. He zeros in on one p in particular.
one of Lardner and a beautiful YOUNG WOMAN. They've been  fishing, and the young woman displays a much larger catch than Lardner.

(into phone) Stanton found him by the wash. Not  hurt too bad, but he took a nasty  bump on the head and he can't remember  who he is. We both think he looks  familiar, but we can't place him.  You bet. He'll be here.
Lardner hangs up and watches Pete looking at the pictures
That's me and my daughter Adele. My  pride and joy. Charms the fish right  out of the lake, she does.
She's very pretty.
Thanks. Well, Sheriff's on his way  over, and maybe we can get to the  bottom of who you are...
Lardner stares at him. Pete takes note, turns toward him.
...sorry 'bout that, but you do look  familiar to me.
Wish I could say the same thing.
The Sheriff's sedan pulls up to the office and SHERIFF CE ELDRIDGE, 45, gets out. As he gets a few steps from the d Harry Trumbo jumps out from around the side of the buildi and stops him.
(excited) Cecil! Cecil, there's a young man in  there...
(startled) Lord love a duck, Harry, you wanna  give me a heart attack right in front  of the doctor's office?
Listen to me! The young man in  there...
Eldridge keeps moving to the door.
(interrupting) Stan Lawson found him unconscious by  the wash this morning, and I'm here  to investigate, and if we find  anything interesting, it'll be in  the paper, so why don't you just...
Harry jumps in front of Eldridge and grabs him by the  shoulders.
Cecil, listen to me!
The sheriff stops.
(breathless) It's Luke.
Sheriff Eldridge is seated across from Pete. He's staring him intently. Silence.
No wallet, huh?
No identification at all. (beat) What're you thinkin', Cecil?
What I'm thinkin' is we got us one  a'two things here. A mystery or a  damn miracle. And by god I can't  tell which. (to Pete) Boy, you say you have no idea who  you are? That right?
Yes.
You ever been in this town before,  to your knowledge?
No. But...
But what?
Well, this place sorta reminds me of  something.
What's that?
"It's a Wonderful Life."
The Jimmy Stewart picture? I remember  that one. Saw it over at the Bijou.  So, you remember that, huh?
"It's a Wonderful Life?"
Or the Bijou. Either one.
I remember the picture... but I don't  remember where I saw it.
The Sheriff rises and crosses to the door.
Doc, with your permission, I want to  bring someone in here. Maybe it'll  jar this young man's memory.
By all means.
Eldridge opens the door.
(to someone offscreen) Harry, why don't you come on in here.

Harry enters the office, doffs his hat, revealing a full  head of snow-white hair. He nods to Eldridge and Lardner, and slowly turns to face Pete. He looks closer... and clo Hesitantly, he takes a couple of steps towards Pete, who  slowly rises out of his chair to meet the old man's gaze. Finally, they're standing practically toe-to-toe.
looks a bit puzzled, but the old man has such a sweet fac
has tears forming in his eyes. A smile turns up the corne of his mouth, and quickly lights up his whole face.
(softly, to Eldridge) Are you saying that he's...
(smiling broadly) Shhhhhh.
Harry takes Pete in his arms and hugs him tightly, buryin his face in Pete's shoulder and sobbing.
I knew all along. I knew you were  alive! Oh, Luke...
Pete doesn't quite know what to think. He clearly has no  idea who this old man is.
(mouth agape in  disbelief) Mother o'god...
(to Pete) Give the man a hug, boy! That's your  father!
Pete looks at Harry. It's not so much that he remembers  anything -- he's swept up in the moment.
My father...?
Pete wraps his arms around Harry and hugs him tightly,  glancing over at
who look on goofily, fighting back tears. They smile at P who smiles back tentatively.
Harry, Pete, Eldridge and Lardner come outside.
C'mon, I'll give you two a lift back  to the Bijou.
The Bijou?
That's where you live.
We live in a theater?
Only one in town. (he opens the car  door for Pete) Get in, son.
(sotto, to Lardner) Ben, when's Delly due back?
(sotto) Tomorrow afternoon... (seized by a thought) ...oh my god...
(sotto) Exactly. Break it to her gently.
Eldridge and Harry get in the car. Lardner comes over to  Pete's back seat window.
Get plenty of rest, Luke. You took a  pretty big wallop there.
He turns to move away, then turns back.
Good to have you back.
Eldridge starts the car and they drive away. (NOTE: Henceforth, "PETE" will be known as "LUKE." It'll easier to keep track of things, since everyone's now call him Luke, anyway. Trust me.)
Harry sits next to the Sheriff, and Luke has the back sea all to himself. He leans forward toward the front seat an taps Harry on the shoulder.
Excuse me... what's your, um, your  name?
Harry, son. Harry.
And... what's my name again?
Albert Lucas Trumbo. But you've been  "Luke" since you were a baby.
Ah. (taking it for a spin) Luke. Luke. I like it.
Luke looks at the town as they drive down Commerce Street
Shops are open for business, TOWNSPEOPLE are going about  their lives. A few stop and watch as the Sheriff's car go by.
How long have I been gone?
Eldridge looks at Harry, who stares ahead.
How long?
Pause. The silence is too thick, and Harry has to answer. He turns around in his seat and faces Luke.
(gently) You never came back from the war. We  were told you were missing and  presumed dead.
When did I leave?
You joined up one month to the day  after Pearl Harbor. January seventh...  nineteen forty-two.
Luke sits back against the back seat and lets this sink i
Nine and-a-half years ago.
Nine and-a-half years...
Comin' up on the Bijou, gents.
Eldridge's car rounds the corner, pulls up and stops.
Here we are.
Well, son, you're home!

Luke peers across the street... his mouth gapes open... HIS POV - THE BIJOU. The Bijou is a decaying, Dada-esque, grab-bag of building styles. It's as though the architect took random parts of Chinese temple, a Mosque, a Pagoda, a Sphinx, a symphony  hall and a slaughterhouse, put them in a bag, gave it a g shake, tossed the contents out onto a blueprint and promp built the result. As a matter of fact, if you didn't know that the place wa "The Bijou," you'd probably wonder what the cryptic messa

was trying to convey from atop the crumbling parapet. And now, the reason for the deteriorated state of the " H J U" sign becomes apparent. Train tracks run right behind the building on an elevated trestle. As we watch, a TRAIN ROARS BY. Everything shakes. It's not an earthquake, it's trainquake. The "J" teeters at a jaunty angle, threatenin to dislodge and tumble down to join its fallen brothers.
stares at the monstrosity. His face is ashen. His heart h sunk to somewhere below his knees. The Bijou. Harry jumps out of the car excitedly.
Thanks for the lift, Cecil.
Don't mention it. Welcome home, Luke.
(faint smile) Thanks.
Luke opens the back door and slowly steps out. Harry grab his arm and pulls a ring of keys from his pocket.
Wait'll you see the inside!
(deadpan) Can't wait.

The interior of the theater fulfills every promise made b the exterior. Moth-eaten velvet-flocked wallpaper hangs i shards and pieces from the walls. It's sort of a cross be a gaudy cathouse and a mausoleum, served up with generous helpings of dust and grime, an almost unbeatable combinat of questionable taste and neglect. Above the center of the lobby hangs what was -- and is -- probably the only truly beautiful item in the whole theat A DELICATE CRYSTAL CHANDELIER. Even under a veneer of dust, the fragile droplets of cut  crystal seem to pick up every available point of light an scatter it in a hundred directions.
Luke and Harry standing below. Luke is lost in a gulf  somewhere between surprise and disgust.
We've been closed for a while.
(smiling wanly) Ah.
Luke walks toward the auditorium doors and slowly, cracks one open.

The ocean of two hundred or so seats on the main floor se to be, for the most part, intact -- although the occasion row seems to have loosed itself from its moorings and hea itself up against the row behind or in front.

is really not much more than a tatty bit of yellowing mus framed by ragged red velveteen drapery. In the tiny orchestra pit, as we will see later, is an ol upright piano. Luke walks a few steps down the aisle. He picks a seat on the aisle near the middle of the theater and sits. As he  does, a CAT, an orange tabby, leaps out from under anothe seat, jets past Luke and disappears down the aisle and  backstage. Harry comes over and sits behind him.
(turning to Harry) Exactly how long has the Bijou been  closed?
Hmmmm... after you left, it was  difficult, and then Lily -- that's  your mother -- she took ill and  died... we haven't shown a picture  since forty-eight.
Why?

(deep breath) Well, after the war, with so many of  the town's boys killed, people around  here didn't much feel like going to  the movies, I guess. Some of 'em  moved away -- Los Angeles, Sacramento,  San Francisco. Wasn't much to keep  'em here, I expect. And now with  this "television" thing -- people  just aren't going out as much as  they used to.
Didn't you have any help?

Oh, I had Irene and Old Tim but they  really couldn't help much. Broke  their hearts when we closed up. Broke  mine, too. (brightening) But now that you're back, well, things  will be different around here, that's  for sure. (rises, grabs Luke's  arm) C'mon, I'll show you where we live.

The small apartment above the projection booth is quite a contrast to the rest of the theater. It's neat as a pin, fairly lit, as Harry has just pulled back the curtains,  allowing the sun to flood the room. A beam of golden light falls across a table, atop which a SEVERAL FRAMED PHOTOS. One of the photos is of the real, much-younger Luke. It's Norman Rockwell scene, at a train depot, with an army-iss olive drab duffel bag slung over his shoulder. He has one arm around Harry and the other around his mother. (And by the way, Pete's resemblance to the real Luke -- e in a nearly 10 year old photo -- is pretty damn startling
The day you shipped out. That was a  proud day for your mother and me.  Last time you saw her. Last time I  saw you.
He smiles.
Till today.
Luke sets it down and picks up another photo, that of a f looking woman. It's a formal portrait, dating perhaps fro the 30's.
That's Lily. Your mother, rest her  soul.
(repeating) Mother. (to Harry) She's beautiful.
(coming over) Well, yes, that she was. She certainly  made this place a home.
He takes the picture from Luke, kisses it, and gently rep it on the table. Luke goes over to the sofa and sits.
(brightly) Can I get you anything? I can put  some coffee on or some...
Harry looks at Luke, who has almost instantly fallen asle on the sofa. He goes to him, gently picks his feet off the floor, lift them onto the sofa. Removes his shoes, sets them on the f
being drawn up Luke's chest.
stands, looks down warmly at his son. Then, suddenly, he' seized by a thought. He turns and crosses to the window.
There's a small picture frame in the window. Harry reache down, gingerly picks it up and turns it around.
It's a single, faded gold star. One war casualty. Harry clutches it to his chest, looks over at the sleepin Luke and smiles.
(softly) When I woke up this morning, my son  was dead. Now, I have my boy again. (closes his eyes) I have my boy again.

It's early morning. Luke is sound asleep, still in his  clothes. In the distance, a train sounds its HORN. Luke rolls over on his back, still asleep, snoring lightl Slowly, he starts to wake up, eyes still closed. Something's strange, though. He frowns. The train is GETT CLOSER. Luke's eyes POP OPEN.
As the train RUMBLES BY, shaking everything in the room,  Luke looks up to see three ancient cherubs staring down a him. Harry, an elderly WOMAN, and an elderly BLACK MAN.
(smiling) 'Morning, Son.
(smiling) Good morning, Luke.
(no expression) 'Mornin'.
Sleep well?
Luke is speechless. It he dreaming this?
They couldn't wait to see you.
Who... are they?
This is the staff of the Bijou.
Oh. What... what time is it?
Six-thirty. I thought we'd get an  early start.
Luke sits up on the sofa and tries to get a little more a He rubs the side of his head that is still bandaged. The elderly woman nudges Harry gently.
Oh, I'm sorry, they know you, but  you don't... you need to be re- introduced. Luke, this is Mrs. Irene  Terwilliger.
Luke stands and shakes MRS. TERWILLIGER'S hand. She's tin seventy if she's a day. She smiles and curtsies slightly. Her eyes sparkle brightly, her manner almost coquettish.
Head cashier and refreshments clerk.   So glad to have you back, my boy! (to Harry) Much more handsome than I remember  him.
And this fine fellow is our head  usher, resident fix-it man and  custodian. Luke, meet Old Tim. (to Old Tim) You remember Luke, don't you?

OLD TIM is -- well, old. His clothes are a tad shabby, bu well maintained, though they hang loosely on his gangly f He wears an old blue knit cap, which he quickly removes a he shakes Luke's hand. He's a man of few words, his manne is painfully shy -- and he never smiles.
Is there a young Tim?
No.
Well, then, why do they call you  "Old Tim?"
Pause.
I'm old.
Harry steps forward, takes Luke's arm.
Well, lots to do, so we'd better get  a move on...

Luke, Harry and Mrs. Terwilliger walk down the aisle towa the screen. Old Time lags a few steps behind. At the orch pit, Harry climbs the steps, crosses the pit. The screen a sea of repair patches. Harry pats it. Dust flies.
'Fraid this has seen better days.  Well, I was meaning to get a new  screen, anyway.
I n-need me a new uniform.
Luke looks at Old Tim, then at Harry.
(to Luke) I promised him a new uniform when we  re-opened. (to Old Tim) And you'll get one, too.
You know, I hate to bring this up,  but screens and uniforms and paint  and repairs are going to take money,  which I'm willing to bet none of us  has.
Silence from the group.
I thought so.
Beat. Harry brightens, clambers down the steps and races the aisle.
Anyone want to see the projector?
are squeakily being cranked together above the din of a f motor. A puff of smoke, then -- BZZZZZZZZZTT -- LIGHT. A  metal door is closed over the arcs.
Harry dances around to the other side of the projector an adjusts the focus on the beam of light. The others look o as he gazes at the screen through the tiny window.
Beautiful. Bright and even from edge  to edge. See for yourself.
The carbons sputter and die. The light flickers out. Harr is crestfallen, turns off the motor.
She's always been a bit tricky.

Mrs. Terwilliger is dusting the concession stand with a r feather duster, a hopeless task. Old Tim is on a rickety  ladder, replacing burned-out bulbs in the chandelier. The orange tabby cat scratches itself on the leg of the  ladder. Old Tim climbs down and catches his breath. Mrs. Terwilli sneezes.
Bless.
Thank you, Timothy.
They both stop their work and glance warily at the door m
(sotto) What do you suppose they're talking  about?
Dunno. Boy's smart.
(brightly) Yes, he seems to be.
Bad for us.
Luke is poring over the ledger books, adding up figures o an old manual adding machine.
Um... Harry? Did I ever keep the  books here?
No, your mother did, then I did after  she passed.
Well, I'm the first one to admit  that I don't know anything about  bookkeeping, but there are some very  interesting things in here.
He scans down a page.
(reading) "February 10, 1942. Picture 'Ball of  Fire.'"
(appreciatively) Gary Cooper. And Barbara Stanwyck.  Yowsa.
(reading) "Eight p.m. showtime, ninety-six  admissions, receipts including  concessions, $84.75... plus one fryer  and two-dozen eggs."
He closes the book and looks expectantly at Harry.
Yes?
"one fryer and two-dozen eggs?"

Forty-two was a lean year around  here. The war had just started...  you were gone less than a month...  and we were coming off a bit of a  drought as I recall. Not everyone  could ante up the price of a ticket,  and a chicken's as good as money if  you ask me. At that time, it meant a  lot to the folks around here to be  able to come to the pictures.
Yeah, I know, but poultry...?

(rhapsodically) I know it's hard to believe, son,  but this place, this little place  this wasn't a theater then, this was  a palace! Any man, woman, child,  you, me, it didn't matter, you bought  your ticket and you walked in and  you...
Harry puts his hand on his chest and sighs.
...you were in a palace. It was like  a dream. It was like heaven, like  you died and went to a palace in  heaven, that's what it was like. And  spotless, too.
Inspired, Harry stands, takes Luke by the arm.
Come with me!
He drags him out of the office and into the lobby.
Mrs. Terwilliger and Old Tim watch as Harry leads Luke th the lobby.

(smiling) Maybe you had problems and worries  out there, but once you came through  that door, they didn't matter anymore.  In here, you were safe. Maybe it was  just an escape from reality, but...  oh, god... it was beautiful.
Harry leads Luke into the auditorium. The car follows, bu Mrs. Terwilliger and Old Tim stay behind.
Harry trots down the aisle and looks up at the screen.

(exuberant) Charlie Chaplin. Keaton and Lloyd.  Swanson. And later on, Clark Gable  and Claudette Colbert and Jimmy  Stewart and James Cagney and Bogart  and Becall and Judy and Mickey...  and Fred and Ginger.
He turns to Luke.
(emphatically) They... were... like... gods!
He points to the screen.

And that... was the altar. Would you  remember if I told you, we felt lucky  to be here, to have the privilege of  watching them? (sadly) This television thing. Why would you  want to sit at home and watch a little  box with a little screen? Because  it's convenient? Because you don't  have to get dressed and put on a  coat and a tie and a hat? Because  you can just... sit there? How can  you call that "entertainment," all  alone in your living room? Where are  the other people? Where's the  audience?
Harry comes over to Luke.
(emphatically) Where's the magic?
He stands behind Luke and whispers in his ear.
I'll tell you. In a place like this,  the magic is all around you. All the  time. Everywhere. In every thing.
He turns Luke around and looks him in the eye.
The trick... is to see it.
Pause.
But I...
Son, I think you loved the Bijou  even more than I did. You've got to  remember that. You've got to.

Still looking at Luke, Harry takes a step back, then slow walks up the aisle, disappearing into the lobby. Luke walks down the aisle. At the edge of the orchestra p he stands looking up at the screen. The orange tabby cat  MEOWS, and Luke glances toward it, standing onstage by th edge of the screen. They exchange looks as we

Doc Lardner is seated in an easy chair, his feet up, read Life magazine. The radio is on, and Patti Page is singing "The Tennessee Waltz." There's a noise offscreen, and Lardner looks up. In the  entrance hall, the front door opens.
enters. She's a strikingly beautiful woman in her late 20 She takes off a felt cap, and her long, auburn hair casca down.
Dad?
Delly? In here.
Lardner rises as Adele comes into the living room. They  embrace warmly.
How'd it go?
Not as bad as I thought it would. I  think I passed.
(kisses her forehead) That's my girl! (he hugs her again) Did you...?
No hiccups, which was good. Who wants  an attorney who gets the hiccups  when she gets nervous? ("serious" lawyer  voice) "Your (hic!) Honor, I (hic!) Object!"
They laugh.
I always told you, baby... (taps her head) ...it's all up here.
Lardner gives her an extra squeeze, continues to hold ont her just a bit too long. Adele detects something amiss.
Dad? What is it?
Beat.
Well, it's...
Adele breaks away from him.
(extreme concern) Oh my god... who died?
on a kitchen table. Offscreen, we HEAR A HICCUP. Then ano Adele's hand reaches into frame.
Lardner stands over Adele, who is seated at the table, ho the glass of water.
Drink slowly.
She raises the glass to her lips.
From the other side of the glass.
It's a particularly gymnastic way in which to drink water but Adele accomplishes it with aplomb. She waits for a mo then hiccups again.
I think (hic!) it's worse (hic!) now.
That always used to work.
Yeah, well it's not everyday you get (hic!) news like this. You're sure he's (hic!) okay? Other than the (hic!) bump on the head?
(hedging) Well...
(hic!) Dad... (hic!)
Lardner sits at the table and takes Adele's hand.
He doesn't remember anything, Delly.  Doesn't know how he got here, doesn't  remember his father, the town, the  Bijou, anyone...
...including me. Right? (hic!)

I'm afraid not. He looked right at  your picture without batting an eye.  But it's probably temporary. He got  all the way to Lawson, so he clearly  knew who he was and what he was doing  until he hit his head. I'm sure it'll  all come back to him. It just takes  a catalyst.
You mean, (hic!) me?
It's possible.
Off Adele's thoughtful hiccuping, we
Luke and Harry, walking along, make a turn onto Commerce  Street, heading for Mabel's. It's still light out, and a  soft breeze skitters some leaves along the sidewalk.
I take breakfast and supper at Mabel's  every day except Sunday. Have for  years, since Lily died. If it weren't  for Mabel, I'd probably starve to  death.
ERNIE COLE, a slight, balding man in his 50s, is locking door of his pharmacy across the street, when he spots Har and Luke.
Harry! Hold on a second!
Ernie runs across the street and, slightly winded, stands before Luke, staring. Luke shoots a glance at Harry, who  taps Ernie on the shoulder.
It's really him, Ernie.
(agape) Well, I'll be...
He sticks his hand out and Luke takes it. Ernie pumps it  enthusiastically.
By god, Luke, if it isn't good to  see you again.
(uncertain) Uh, thanks. Good to see you again,  too, uh...
Ernie.
...Ernie.
(still at a lose) Well, I'll be...
We were just gonna get some supper.  Would you like to join us?
Would I ever!
The three walk toward the diner, but before they get two  steps, they hear:
Is that Luke Trumbo?
They turn to see a stout woman, KATIE RUTHERFORD, 40s, ru toward them. She rushes right into a very surprised Luke' arms and hugs him tightly.
Oh, Luke, it's so good to have you  back!
Katie, would you like to join us for  dinner? The more, the merrier.

The diner is packed. In addition to Ernie and Katie, MEN, WOMEN and CHILDREN occupy every seat and table, and many  more are standing, even hanging out the door. At the focus of the crowd are Luke and Harry, seated at t counter. Harry is leisurely eating a chicken dinner, whil Luke is working on a steak. A young man seated at the opp side of the counter is speaking. He's CARL LEFFERT, 30s.
(eagerly) Hey, Luke, remember the time you and  me, we was playing with firecrackers  and the one you was lighting blew up  too soon and singed all the hair  offa my head?
A few people shake their heads, smile and laugh.
Uh, no. What happened?
(deflated) Well... um, all the hair got singed  offa my head. It was pretty funny.
A couple of TITTERS are heard.
Oh.
Even my eyebrows. But they grew back.
Luke leans toward Harry, who never looks up from his chic
Carl. Friend of yours from high  school. Everybody calls him "Cueball."
(sincerely) Oh, hi Cue... Carl. Sorry.
(brightening) Oh, heck, that's all right. It's  just good to have you back. Isn't  that right, Bob? Hey, Luke, you  remember my brother Bob? You two  joined up the same day.
Luke smiles and nods at the young man sitting next to Car

is a good-looking fellow, a few years older than Carl. Hi face is pale and downcast, and he wears a cap pulled down his forehead. He looks up at Luke with hollow eyes. Bring his right hand up, pushes the brim of his cap up. Except  there's no hand there -- it's a hook.
(quietly) Hey, Bob. Good to meet you.
Bob doesn't react. He glances away, and for a moment, his eyes meet Mabel's. She smiles warmly. He turns away. Ernie Cole pipes up.
Luke, I know there's a question that's  on everybody's mind.
What's that?
Well, now that you're back, what're  your plans?
All eyes on Luke. He freezes, having just taken a forkful food in his mouth. Harry jumps in.
Gonna re-open the Bijou, that's what.
A MURMUR goes through the crowd. Stanton Lawson, standing behind Luke, taps him on the shoulder.
That true?
(on the spot) Well... we're gonna try.
That's a lot of work, son. Place's  been closed, what, three, four years  now. Gonna be tough.
If it's tough, that means it's worth  doing.
Someone shouts "That's the spirit!," another shouts "Hear hear!," and a chorus of VOICES join in agreement.
Hey, where's Spencer Wyatt?
Uh, back here, Mr. Mayor.
Well, come on out here so's we can  see you.

SPENCER WYATT steps around from the back of the crowd nea the door. He's a tall, dark-haired, gangly, bespectacled  kid, no more than 19 or 20. Painfully shy, he clutches a  clarinet case to his chest. He timidly smiles and waves a Luke, who smiles and nods back.
Hey, Luke.
Hi, Spencer.
Spence, that band of yours -- you  think they're ready to play? (to Luke) Spencer and his pals went ahead and  got together a good ol' big band.
We've been practicing... uh, sure, I  guess.
Well, how about tomorrow night, eight  p.m., in city hall square? What I'm  proposin' is a "Welcome Home Luke"  celebration.
Vociferous general AGREEMENT from the crowd -- which is  quickly quieted by a MURMUR, which starts at the front do The crowd parts and grow silent, revealing a woman standi in the doorway.

She locks eyes with Luke. Her hand goes to her mouth and eyes well up. Slowly, she moves around the counter, the c moving aside for her. She stands in front of Luke, who has stood up to meet her Her eyes moist, she looks up at him.
Do you... remember me?
I've seen you before. Your picture...
Mabel, clutching a napkin, leans over to Katie.
(sotto) Look!
...but I don't think I remember you.
Adele leans up and kisses him softly. He looks at her.
But I'll sure try.
As Mabel and Katie dab at their eyes, we
Adele and Luke stroll down the street side by side. She l at him for a long moment.
What.
No, I... I just wondering where you've  been all this time.
Me too.
You look... different.
I do?
Yeah, a little. I think you grew an  inch or so. And you've lost weight.
I did? Huh!
Tentatively, she takes his hand and holds it. From behind them, we HEAR A SHUFFLING SOUND. Adele turns...
Keeping a discreet distance, EVERYONE from the diner is  following them. Adele turns and addresses the crowd.
(to the group) You can all go home, now. He's not  going anywhere.
Go on home, folks. And thanks for  the welcome.
Harry comes over.
I'll be home in a little while, Harry.  Don't wait up.
You two have a lot of catching up to  do, I guess.
You bet.
Goodnight, son. (tips his hat) 'Night, Delly.
And the rest of the crowd disperses, variously wishing th pair goodnight. Luke and Adele watch them disperse.
There. We're alone.
They turn and start walking.
Then why do I feel like we're still  being shadowed?
Well... where can we go?
Adele brightens.
I know a place. Come on!
She grabs his hand and they run toward the town square.
Adele and Luke stand by the front steps.
City hall?
You must not remember anything. Come  on.
She grabs his hand and they run to the side of the buildi

Adele and Luke stand by a basement window, inches off the ground. She looks around. Certain the coast is clear, she pounds on the window in three "special" places, and it po up and open. She looks at Luke.
You first.
Why me?
Be a gentleman. You have to help me  down.
As Luke climbs in, we
Slowly, the muslin is drawn off, revealing A STATUE OF A  KNEELING SOLIDER, praying before a soldier's grave. We sl PAN DOWN from the top of the statue...
When we were kids, my Dad was mayor,  and you and me and a bunch of others  used to come down here all the time.
looking up at the statue in this city hall basement stora room, lit only by a single shaft of moonlight from the wi The muslin covering lay bunched at their feet.
Of course, there was a lot more room  before they stuck the memorial down  here.
(looks at the door) How'd they get it inside?
Through the door. It comes apart.
She moves to the memorial. Squinting, she examines its ba
Your name's on here. See?
Luke comes over.

head_text.subj: ON THE BASE OF THE MEMORIAL

text: Right here. "Albert Lucas Trumbo."
And all the others. I knew them all. So did you. We went school with most of them.
It doesn't seem right, this being  down here. It ought to be where people  can see it.

After they commissioned it, no one  could ever agree on where to put it.
