Mr. Fitts, with all due respect, I  think Lawson needs the Bijou a bit  more than it needs a super market.  And I think Lawson deserves the Bijou.  There's not a lot that can be done  to help us get past the pain we've  all felt...
He looks at Harry and smiles.
...but I think a good dose of magic  is as good a place as any to start.
The council members MURMUR amongst themselves, then:
(eagerly) Motion to encourage the citizenry of  Lawson to help out the Bijou in any  way they can...
(a subtle reminder) ...short of the allocation of city  funds...
(agreeing) ...short of allocation of city funds.
(enthusiastically) Seconded!
(brightly) Motion on the floor, discussion open,  discussion closed, all those in favor  signify by saying "aye."
AYE!
Hearing no opposition, the motion is  carried! Congratulations, Luke, you  got yourself a town to help you out!

As the entire city council and the Bijou trio looks on, L moves to the memorial and pulls down the huge piece of mu covering it. Harry steps forward and gathers some of it i his arms. Ernie and Daley step forward and look up at the monument. Ernie touches the names of his two sons inscribed on the  base of the monument.
(slowly) You know, this really ought to be  out where people can see it.
Luke overhears this last, and as he smiles, he turns to H who brightens as he pulls a large section of the muslin t between his outstretched arms...

Harry's on a ladder, snipping the cords holding up the ol screen, which is dropping, bit-by-bit, into the arms of L and Adele, who are surrounded by a group of LITTLE KIDS,  watching the goings-on in wide-eyed awe. Harry snips the last line, and the rest of the old screen drops down on Luke's head. Suddenly... LUKE'S A GHOST!! H raises his arms and plays the bogeyman for the kids, who  scream in mock terror and scatter, as Harry and Adele lau

Old Tim and Harry carry a dilapidated row of seats up the aisle, as Adele and Mabel move in, tearing up the rotten  carpeting and sweeping up the dust and debris. The men are having a tough time carrying the seats, and j as they're about to drop the row, someone rushes in next Harry and grabs his end. It's Carl Leffert. A second late someone else grabs Old Tim's end.
has a good purchase on the seats with his good hand and h hook. He nods to Old Tim, who steps away, mopping his bro Luke smiles as he sees this from the front of the auditor

Harry, Stanton and Mrs. Terwilliger, with the help of Ave Wyatt and his son Spencer, tear down the rotting draperie and scrape off the wallpaper covering the lobby walls. Th as Harry, Spencer and Stanton sand down the walls, Avery Mrs. Terwilliger hand them freshly-mixed cans of red wall paint and brushes. Immediately, they all set to work pain

Luke is on the roof of the theater, pliers in hand and to box nearby. He's just straightened out the "J" and he ste back... carefully... to admire his handiwork. For the fir time in a long time, the sign actually reads, "THE BIJOU. But not for long. Luke tenses... the building starts  shaking... and the train passes by behind the theater. Lu lunges out of the way as three letters shake lose and fal Once again, the sign reads, " HE B J U."  Luke winces.
Ernie Cole and Avery Wyatt stand solemnly at the front of small group gazing at the base of the war memorial, as it takes shape in a prominent place in the square...

Harry is on a ladder, attaching the final spring stretche to a corner of the muslin. It snaps into place, and voila new screen! Luke, Adele, Doc Lardner, and Sheriff Eldridg standing below, applaud enthusiastically.

As work progresses all around her, Mrs. Terwilliger has j finished dusting off the piano. She opens the keyboard co and trails her hand delicately over the keys. She sits, c her eyes, and begins to play -- Chopin's Op. 10 Etude No. delicate, flowing music. Even though the piano is a bit o of tune, it's still beautiful. As she plays, all the work slowly comes to a halt. Before long, all eyes are on her. Everyone's listening. Transported. After a moment, she stops. Overcome. Everyone applauds. Surprised, Mrs. Terwilliger stands, and, blushing, bows.
That was beautiful.
I taught you that.
I can play the piano?
(all fluttery) Oh dear, yes. You were an excellent  student, before all that clarinet  nonsense. You loved Chopin. You used  to call it "heaven music." "Teach me  some heaven music," you used to say.
She sits at the piano.
Sit. Play with me.
No, I...
Some of it might come back to you.
Reluctantly, Luke sits down to her left. As she begins to play a Chopin waltz, she encourages him to keep the 3/4 t
That's good... that's good...

But it's clear Luke has no idea what he's doing. He's jus plunking bass notes. But after a moment, the bass figures he's improvising start to change -- and before long, it's transformed into the eight-to-the-bar figure of a boogie  woogie beat. Mrs. Terwilliger stops playing, annoyed.
Really, Luke! That's no way to treat  Mr. Chopin!
She stands and moves away. Luke keeps playing, grinning m he's loving it! After a moment, Spencer Wyatt runs over a takes Mrs. Terwilliger's place, improvising the top half Luke's bass line.
is tapping his foot to the beat. He turns to Adele and sa
I taught him that.
Off Adele cracking up. THE MONTAGE CONTINUES...
Luke and all the letters up again. He steps back, checks watch, and like clockwork, the rumbling begins and a trai goes by. This time, however, only the "J" tips over at a  jaunty angle. Luke smiles.

Luke, Adele and Harry, wearing coveralls, sit at the coun devouring hefty plates of turkey with dressing and mashed potatoes and gravy. Luke's and Adele's hair is practicall white from plaster dust and Harry's face and hands are st with paint specks. At the other side of the counter, Mabel is chatting amiab with Bob Leffert. She smiles at him warmly, then turns to refill Harry's coffee cup. Harry thanks her, then turns b to the newspaper he's reading.

head_text.subj: THE FRONT PAGE OF THE LAWSON JOURNAL-AMERICAN

text: Prominent is the black-and-white photo of a little boy an policeman holding up Pete's jacket, with the accompanying headline:
Hollywood Writer Feared Dead Were Red Agents Involved?

Luke's standing near the sign. He yells to Adele, down be on the ground. She, in turn, yells to Harry, standing nea switch panel behind the candy counter. He throws the swit ...and the sign lights up beautifully! Then, they all fee the rumble -- the train rolls past, and, although they ra and shake, no letters fall. A CHEER goes up from Adele, H and the small crowd of ONLOOKERS below. Delighted, Luke t a formal bow. The boogie-woogie ends as we
Complete and polished, standing proudly in the center of square.

It's a clear, balmy day, and the whole town is turned out Mayor Ernie Cole is at the podium. He finishes his remark then picks up the two faded gold stars representing the l lives of his sons. He holds them up, high above his head.

One-by-one, the gold stars of the town's boys are solemnl held aloft by their loved ones. Luke and Harry stand at the side of the square, looking o at the sea of four or five dozen gold stars being held al Luke catches a glimpse of a man in an army uniform...

It's Bob Leffert, standing with Mabel, looking very sharp his dress greens. He brings his hook-hand up and salutes  smartly. Mabel takes his good hand, squeezes it as she bl back tears. Luke smiles at this scene as Harry wipes his eyes and put his arm around Luke's shoulder, pulls him close and kisse him on the forehead.

The Lawson High School Marching Band is set up on the ste of City Hall, playing the "Star Spangled Banner." They ar being conducted by their director, MR. PHILLIPS. Luke and Harry, hands over their hearts, watch and sing along. The Luke takes a closer look at the DRUM MAJOR...
a tall young man wearing an ornate brocaded red and white uniform with "LHS" emblazoned across the chest.
He has an idea. The anthem ends, and Luke excuses himself and moves forward, buttonholing Mr. Phillips as he comes  down the steps...
Luke and Adele are on ladders, hanging letters on the mar which reads:
Harry comes outside and gets their attention. Grandly, he gestures toward the door, and out strides

wearing his new uniform -- it's the Lawson High School dr major's uniform, modified here and there. "B-I-J-O-U" is  proudly emblazoned across his chest in gold brocaded lett Luke and Adele applaud. Old Time looks up at them -- AND

Old Tim stands at attention, clutching the front door han Mrs. Terwilliger, wearing a new dress, her hair newly and perfectly coiffed, stands at the ready at her candy count ready to sell tickets and refreshments. Harry and Luke nervously pace the lobby. Luke checks his  watch. It's time. He shakes Harry's hand, and nods to Old Tim, who swings the door open...
Immediately, PATRONS come flooding into the theater. Luke exchanges surprised glances with Harry -- then walks outs
Luke comes out and looks down the block.
The line of PATRONS stretches two deep down the block and around the corner. Luke smiles. Success.

Luke's selling tickets from behind the candy counter whil Mrs. Terwilliger sells refreshments to a line of CUSTOMER Luke sells a ticket to a WOMAN, who moves away, revealing BOB LEFFERT AND MABEL. Luke smiles at Bob, who smiles back, his eyes now fairly  dancing with life. He plunks down his admission, and Luke hands him two tickets, which he takes with his hook-hand. Mabel smiles at Luke, takes Bob's good hand, and they mov away, revealing A FARMER AND HIS WIFE, 50s. The Farmer steps up and holds out a plucked chicken by it neck. Luke, surprised, jumps back -- then smiles, pulls off two tickets, and exchanges them for the chicken.

The only light back here is the light of the movie, spill through the screen. Luke is straightening up the backstag storage area, when Adele taps him on the shoulder. He tur and she throws her arms around his neck and kisses him. S hands him a paper to read.
Luke angles it so he can read it by the light of the scre
California State Bar Association
has PASSED the State Bar examination.
Luke, thrilled, grabs Adele and picks her up, twirling he around with joy. He sets her down and kisses her passiona

Harry is frantically threading the changeover projector. bell on the running projector DINGS! once, signalling tha the reel is coming to an end. Harry looks out the window the screen, then back to the task at hand.

Luke comes out of the office carrying a folded movie post With a satisfied smile, he walks through the lobby, admir how handsome the old place looks. Old Tim, snappily attir in his uniform, is sweeping a tiny pile of debris into a  dustpan. Mrs. Terwilliger is straightening up the candy  counter. All is well. Luke goes to the lobby's poster case. He opens it, and un a brand-new one-sheet poster for "SAND PIRATES" -- the sa design as the one-sheet we saw in Pete's apartment. Methodically, he thumbtacks the poster up and closes the  case. As Luke passes the auditorium doors, a MAN comes out of t theater and crosses to the candy counter. The door stays  open for a moment, and Luke decides to duck inside and ca a bit of the picture.

The second-to-last reel of a black-and-white early-50's  programmer. It's nighttime in the desert. A huge full moo hangs over a B-movie soundstage version of the pyramids. GREGORY, a dark, handsome leading man in a pith helmet is engaged in a fierce swordfight with KHALID, the villain. Pete takes a seat on the aisle near the door.
You don't think you can win this, do  you?
Khalid lunges and draws Gregory's blood.
(ala "Khalid") "Ha! I'd say I was winning!"
Ha! I'd say I was winning!
Luke's look is "How did I know he was gonna say that?" Onscreen, an EVIL HENCHMAN is sneaking up behind Gregory.
"Gregory! Look out!"
Gregory! Look out!
Pete did it again. Onscreen, Gregory turns and kills the Henchman, then quic dispatches Khalid. He stands over the body, catches his b and says:
It's all right, Rebecca.
Is he dead?
Yes, Rebecca. He's dead.
REBECCA, a beautiful American woman, comes into view and  takes our attention because she's being played by Sandra  Sinclair, Pete Appleton's ex-girlfriend...
His mouth is gaping open. He stares at the screen.
(a whisper) Sandra...?
Luke stands. Confused, he stumbles backward, moving into lobby as the Man goes back into the auditorium with his  popcorn and the door closes.
Luke is staring at the closed auditorium doors. Old Tim a Mrs. Terwilliger take note of his odd behavior.
Luke? Dear, are you all right?
Without answering, Luke turns and runs to the poster case

Forget the cheesy B-movie artwork. As Luke looks at the  poster, it's clear that he's remembering something. He lo at the picture of Sandra -- then scans down to the credit block at the bottom of the poster. His eyes lock upon
My god... my god... no...
Suddenly, all of Pete Appleton's worries have come crashi down on him... ...because he remembers...
The warning bell DINGS! twice, but the changeover project carbon arcs keep sputtering and the motor keeps dying.
(pleading) Oh, baby, make your daddy happy...

Harry's trying to keep the projector going, as the previo reel is about to end. Given no other choice, he finally g the changeover projector a good swift kick. It hums to life. A perfect changeover. Harry pets the  projector.
You're a good girl. No matter what I  say.

As he turns away, he feels a sudden, sharp pain in his le arm. Wincing, he grabs his arm, staggers back towards a c and sits heavily. He tries to clear his throat, but it dissolves into a hac choking COUGH. He tries to stand, but drops to his knees, clutching his left arm harder than before.
(in pain) Oh, Jesus...
Harry falls to the floor, and as he does
breaks in the projector gate... flap! Flap! Flap!...

Luke is still staring at the poster, lost in thought. Offscreen, we HEAR the audience WHISTLING AND HOOTING in  reaction to the broken film. Mrs. Terwilliger has been calling Luke's name, but he doe come out of his stupor until Old Tim comes up behind him spins him around...
Mr. Luke!
Luke stares wide-eyed at the old man.
Luke! Luke, something's wrong!
The film broke, and I can't raise Harry on the house phon
(still dazed) What?
You've got to talk to them before  they tear the theater apart!
Finally, Luke pulls himself together, hears the audience  noise, and moves toward the auditorium doors.
Amid the shouting and tossing of popcorn and debris, Luke tries to regain his composure as he strides down the aisl toward the stage.
Come on, folks, this happens every  once in a while, just settle down...
The crowd quiets down a bit. Luke shields his eyes from t light and calls up to the projection booth.
Harry! Harry, why don't you cut the  projector and bring up the house  lights?
No reaction. Just the flickering beam of light.
Harry? Harry...?
Luke, gripped by a sudden fear, rushes up the aisle and i the lobby. The crowd goes silent...
Old Tim and Mrs. Terwilliger watch as Luke tears into the lobby and makes for the balcony stairs...
...and charges between the seats and up the stairs to the projection booth.
Luke bursts in the sees Harry on the floor. He rushes ove and kneels down next to him.
Jesus...
(with difficulty) The film broke...
I know, I know... keep still.
A MAN pops his head into the projection booth door.
(to the man) Get Doc Lardner.

Harry is in bed, eyes closed. Doc Lardner has a stethosco to his chest. He leans up and pats Harry's hand. He stands and comes over to Luke and Adele, who are near door. Just outside, angling for a view into the room, are Old Tim and Mrs. Terwilliger.
It's a pretty massive heart attack.  His lungs have filled with fluid,  and, well... it seems as though his  body is just... shutting down.
Can we get him to the hospital?
Even if we could, and the move didn't  kill him, there'd be very little we  could do there that we can't do here. (puts his hand on  Luke's shoulder) I'm sorry.
Harry's eyelids flutter.
(weakly) Did you... did you...
Luke rushes to Harry's side and takes his hand.
I'm here.
Did you... did you...
Did I what?
(irritated) Did you fix the damn film? It broke  in the last reel.
I know. Everyone went home. We offered  them refunds.
Anybody take it?
A few.
(closes his eyes) Vultures...
Luke smiles.
I'm not happy about this, mind you,  but if I have to go, at least I'm  going in my own bed, the same bed my  Lily died in, and... knowing that my  son is alive. That's not too shabby,  is it?
You're not going anywhere, Harry.
Don't tell me, I know about these  things. I've seen it before. It's  all right. It's... all right. You're  here. Oh, God, I love you, son.
Harry smiles.  Luke kisses his hand and leans up, whisper in Harry's ear:
And I love you... Dad.
Harry smiles faintly, looks at Luke. He nods, then closes his eyes.
(softly) Oh, so... much... lighter...

Slowly, Harry exhales. His face relaxes, completely at pe He doesn't breathe again. Luke looks at Harry's face for a moment. Then as the tear well up, he leans over and ever-so-gently places a kiss o Harry's forehead.
It's a beautiful, bright, sunny day. Luke and Adele stand the front of the large group of mourners. REVEREND COLEMA 50s, conducts the service.

We commit to the earth the mortal  remains of Harry Bernard Trumbo,  safe in the knowledge that his  immortal soul is at peace and at  last reunited with his beloved Lillian  in the bosom of the Lord. Let us  pray.
Everyone bows their heads.
"The Lord is my shepherd, I shall  not want, he maketh me to lie down  in green pastures..."

Luke looks up at the sky, then steps forward and lays a s rose on Harry's casket. Then, as everyone surreptitiously watches, he turns and walks away from the gravesite, towa the cemetery entrance. Adele watches Luke depart...
...and she's not alone. Agents Saunders and Brett are wat everything from their car, which is parked nearby. As Luke walks away, Saunders snaps his photo with a long- lens camera...

head_text.subj: THE BASE OF THE WAR MEMORIAL,

text: and Luke's name inscribed there.
Luke stands in front of the memorial, head bowed. After a moment, he sits, leaning against the memorial.
Lost in thought, he buries his face in his hands.
Mind if I join you?
Luke looks up, squinting. Adele stands above him, backlit the golden light of the sundown.
Sure.
She sits next to him. Tentatively, she touches his should He leans into her, and she enfolds her arm in his. Pause.
Your father said... that I would  start to remember things.
Suddenly, Adele feels as though she's walking on eggshell
(slowly) What... do you remember?
Well... everything. It started coming  back a couple of days ago. I remember  everything now.
I see...
Delly. I'm... I'm not... Harry wasn't  my father. And I'm not... I'm not  Luke.
She closes her eyes. All her suspicions are suddenly  confirmed.
(adrift) Oh...
Her tears start, and she moves to hug Luke -- but instead she starts hitting him, flailing, beating on his chest. H hugs her tightly, and she completely lets go.

(crying) Oh, god, I knew! I knew! I knew from  the start! I wanted you to be Luke!  I wanted you to be alive! You're so  much like him, you have no idea. No  wonder everyone else accepted you!  You don't know what you -- what Luke  meant to this town, suddenly being  alive! You don't know what this town  lost! You just don't know...
She pulls away, stands, and looks him in the eye. Luke ri
(sobbing uncontrollably) I knew you weren't Luke! And I tried  not to fall in love with you! And...  I don't even know your name! Oh,  god...
Luke moves toward her. She backs away.
I fell in love with you, too, Delly.  Only now I don't know how I feel,  about you or about anything. I only  think I know how Luke would feel.
She's still sobbing. He moves to her, takes her in his ar
Delly, shhhhhh...
(pulling away) No... I can't... I have to... I  can't...
She runs off, crying...
making short work of a steak and eggs. As he powers down meal, Agents Saunders and Brett, distinctly out-of-place their dark suits and hats, enter the diner. They take not of Eldridge, and come over.
Are you the sheriff?
And I got the uniform to prove it.
I'm Special Agent Walter Saunders,  this is Special Agent Steven Brett,  FBI. May we have a word with you?
They flash identification, which Eldridge notes.
(gesturing) Please, sit.
They sit across from Eldridge. As Saunders speaks, Agent  Brett pulls a photo from his coat pocket.

A couple of days ago, a county flood  control maintenance crew pulled a  car out of the Lawson Wash ocean  outlet. They checked its registration,  and when the owner was identified,  they notified us.
Agent Brett slides the photo toward Eldridge.
It's Peter Appleton -- Luke.
(smiling) Well, that'd be Luke Trumbo. Looks  like you boys've solved a little  mystery we've had going on for a few  months.
Sir, that's a photo of man named  Peter Appleton. He's been missing  from Los Angeles for close to three  months now.
What? No, there's got to be a...
Sheriff -- this man is a suspected  communist.
(Oh, and by the way, from here on, he's PETE again.) Pete sits across from Eldridge, Saunders and Brett. The  silence in the room is thick.
Am I under arrest?
Eldridge glances at Agent Saunders, who stares at Pete  impassively.
Well, no, but these gentlemen would  like to get some answers...
I don't know what else to tell you.  I wasn't hiding out. I hit my head  and I didn't remember anything until  a few days ago.
Now that you remember who you are,  were you planning on telling anyone  your true identity?
I already have.
Who?
My girlfriend. If she still is...
(checking his notebook) Would that be Miss Sinclair?
(ironic smile) No. No, not Miss Sinclair. I'm talking  about Adele Lardner.
Agent Saunders glances at Eldridge.
The doctor's daughter. She was Luke  Trumbo's sweetheart.
Pause.
Mr. Appleton, I have reason to believe  you're holding something back, and  that just rubs me the wrong way. (pause) Sir, are you a communist?
(firmly) No. Absolutely not.
All right. All right. We'll see.
Pete comes out into the bright midday sun. It takes a mom for his eyes to adjust, and when they do, he becomes awar of perhaps TWENTY PEOPLE lining the sidewalk in front of station.

We recognize several of the people. Carl Leffert. Bob Lef and Mabel Lanier. Daley Thornhill. Katie Rutherford. Stan Lawson. Now, there's nothing in the least bit threatening about the gathering -- and that's what's so disturbing ab it. They're not an angry mob, they're just standing there running the gamut of emotions. Shock. Disillusionment. Betrayal. It's an awkward moment. Pete doesn't quite know how to re He wants to go over and talk to them, but he wouldn't kno what to say. He wishes one of them would talk to him, jus say something, anything. But no one does. Then, Bob Leffert turns away from Pete. He shoves his hoo hand into his pocket and sullenly moves away, followed by Mabel, then his brother, then the others... ...leaving Pete alone.

Old Tim, in his doorman's uniform, stands by the open, em door. Mrs. Terwilliger, behind the candy counter, wipes up an  imaginary spill, a full wheel of unsold tickets by her el Pete anxiously paces the lobby. He looks into THE AUDITORIUM. Every seat is empty. He glances at his watch, then turns to Old Tim and Mrs.  Terwilliger:
Let's close up.
As Mrs. Terwilliger and Old Tim silently shamble off, Pet goes over and flips OFF several light switches. Most of t theater goes dark.
Pete sits leaning up against the base of the dark sign. A gentle breeze tousles his hair as he gazes up at the star After a moment, he HEARS footsteps coming up the ladder t the roof.
Who's that?
It's me.
Adele climbs onto the roof, comes over and sits down next Pete.
Hi.
Hi.
Pause.
I'm sure a lot of people down in  L.A. are worried sick about you.
Yeah? I'm sure a lot more people  down in L.A. want a piece of me.
He turns to her.
This Luke was a pretty good guy,  wasn't he?
(wistful smile) Oh, yes. Yes, he was.
Well... let me tell you, I'm not  Luke. I know who I am now, and you  don't. And... I don't like me very  much.
(changing the subject) You know, it's going to take me a  while to get used to calling you  Pete. (she takes it for a  spin) Pete. Pete. It's a nice name.
Thanks, I like it. I think.
Pause.
Delly, I want to do the right thing.
Pete can't believe he just said that -- but he did.
I believe you.
The truth is, I'm a lot of things,  but communist isn't one of them.
But if you only went to one meeting,  why does anyone care? Besides, why  should it even matter if you were a  communist?

Come on, Delly, look at the country  today. We're fighting communists in  Korea, we're paranoid about the  Russians, we've got this thing with  the Rosenbergs and the atomic bomb... (bitterly) You think they want "suspected  communists" entertaining the American  public with party propaganda like,  gosh I don't know, "Sand Pirates of  the Sahara?"

Forget about all that. You want to  do the right thing? Then defend your  name. If someone says something about  you that's untrue, you have to stand  up and say so. I know the law, and  the law's on your side.
Beat.
What about you, Delly?
I am, too.
Pete smiles and puts his arms around her.
You'll stand by me?
Whatever happens.
They kiss, and we

There's a thick bank of coastal fog just down the road,  obscuring any view of the ocean a mile away. It's deadly  quiet as gas station owner RORY, late 60s, pulls up and p his Model A truck. He gets out, and an big old German  Shepherd, LOTTIE, jumps out of the truck bed. Rory moves to the door, and is about to put his key in th lock, when Lottie starts whining, looking toward the fog  bank and sniffing the air expectantly.
Whatsit, girl?

He stops -- he hears something, too -- a LOW RUMBLE. Lott starts BARKING. The RUMBLE is getting LOUDER. Rory's gett worried. He looks at THE FOG BANK. It's starting to GLOW from within. Lottie's barking gets  LOUDER and angrier. Suddenly, a large black car punches o of the fog bank and tears down the road. It's followed by another, and another -- and perhaps a dozen more cars and trucks, all heading hell-bent-for-leather toward the town Rory moves toward Lottie, trying to quiet her as the cars fly past the station.
Shhhhh. I know, Lottie. This time, I  thought it was the Martians for sure.

The place is bedlam, overflowing with REPORTERS, NEWSREEL CAMERA CREWS, PHOTOGRAPHERS, you name it. A RADIO CREW is broadcasting in front of Mabel's Diner. T REPORTER is on-the-air, hugging his microphone, speaking  above the din. Mabel stands next to him, his hand on her  shoulder. Bob Leffert stands nearby, grim.

I'm here with Mabel Lanier, the owner  of the diner here on Commerce Street  where Appleton often took meals.  Mrs. Lanier, tell me, what are your  thoughts about having such a  celebrated suspected communist in  your midst all this time?

Well, its kinds hard to believe,  'cause Luke -- I mean Peter -- is  such a... I mean, since he's been  back, I've never seen the town so  happy and all. It's like he gave us  some... I don't know... some hope, I  guess.

What she's referring to folks, is  yet another bizarre twist in this  story. Not only is Appleton alive,  but he's been suffering from amnesia  and living here in Lawson, where,  due to a startling resemblance,  everyone in town for the last three  months has taken him for one of  Lawson's dead war heroes, Albert  Trumbo...
(a catch in her voice) Luke. We always called him Luke.
Mabel glances at Bob, who lowers his head.
Pete is at the desk, staring into space. Adele leans agai the radiator behind him. The silence in the room is thick Across the desk from Pete sits Leo Kubelsky.
The FBI can't arrest you, because  you haven't done anything wrong.
Well, that's a relief. I understand  they usually don't let that stop  them.

However... you're gonna be subpoenaed  to testify before the Un-American  Activities Committee when they open  hearings in Los Angeles. Now, if you  play ball and tell them what they  want to hear, they'll clear you.
And I won't be a communist anymore.
Exactly.
So it doesn't make any difference  that I'm not one now, and have never  been one.
Leo stands and walks to the window.
Kid, don't get philosophical with  me. This is a game, but it's not  your game. You play by their rules,  or they'll ruin you. And they have  the power to do it.
Doesn't it bother anyone that this  is a perversion of democracy?
Leo turns to her and smiles. His tone is charmingly matte of-factly, not condescending in the least.

Darling, don't kid yourself. We don't  have a "democracy" in this country.  The Declaration of Independence? The  Constitution? These are pieces of  paper with signatures on 'em. And  you know what a piece of paper with  a signature is? It's a contract. And  you know what a contract is? Something  that can be re-negotiated at any  time. It just so happens that the  House Un-American Activities Committee  is re-negotiating the contract this  time around.
